One thing that I have found while implementing my own metadata library is that metadata could be a lot better. I've had to do a lot of manual editing to get things looking nice.

author: Paul J Miller
notes: Written in 2015, this seems even more relevant today in 2023. The Web shouldn't die, but content that exists solely to sell ads should. The current state of the Web is problematic due to issues like surveillance capitalism, monopolies, and social media's negative impact. Show the Web in its current form die so that something better can emerge in its place? This article is another call for people to take ownership of their data and participate in building a better web.

notes: Is the Internet broken, or has the way use it created the issues we see today? We could all take accountability for how we engage with content on the Internet and each other to avoid things such as sharing misleading or false information and work to make the Internet a better place for everyone.

title: How to fix the internet
author: Paul J Miller
notes: Written in 2015. Should the tech giants control user-created content like videos, podcasts, music and blogs? Think of a web where standard and open formats such as .video, .podcast, .blog, and .tweet exist. They are not tied to apps rented to you by the tech giants. An entire ecosystem exists for users to choose how to consume this open and free content. I love these ideas and would love to work on something to push this...

notes: Another article stresses the importance of owning and controlling your digital content rather than relying on social media or other platforms. Owning your content gives control over its distribution and longevity and reduces the risk of losing it due to how the tech giants feel about a particular service. Bryce offers practical tips and tools to create and host your own website or blog.

notes: I don't care for the making money parts, but the other points are solid.

notes: We all fall trap to this. Create and share your work with the world instead of holding back and waiting for perfection. Putting oneself out there and learning from mistakes is essential to the creative process. Learning in public is one of the fun things about the Web.

notes: I'm interested to see how this works out for The Verge. Their redesign aims to provide a better user experience by improving the navigation, reducing clutter, and emphasizing the content. I've enjoyed reading so far and paying attention to who the authors of the blog posts are.

notes: It is evident when a website has been crafted with care and excitement. It can enhance user experience and improve the overall perception of a brand. I love discovering new websites where the webmaster has done just that. It's great to stand out from the crowd and helps me identify whether a real person is behind the website.

title: A Web that Reflects People and their Val… — Jacky Alciné
author: Jacky Alciné
notes: Dive into the current state of the internet and the rise of decentralised projects attempting to offer an alternative to the tech giants. Jacky expresses their desire for an alternative social networking system that allows them to publish and share content while maintaining control over their data. I like emphasising this exact message in every conversation about posting your content online.

title: Smashmouth's White Magic
author: Zach Mandeville
description: Older esoteric standup piece
notes: Zach dives into Smashmouth's hidden, mystical significance, particularly the references to hermetic alchemy in their music. It hilariously ends with a warning of the dangers of bands like Third Eye Blind, who use the occult arts to obfuscate and block spiritual clarity.

title: Why is your site like this?
author: Di
notes: Fellow small web enthusiast Di explores why they write, including the desire to create something beautiful and meaningful, the need to process their thoughts and emotions, and the hope to connect with others through their writing. Writing is an act of self-discovery and a way to make sense of the world around them.

title: A Web Renaissance
author: Anil Dash
description: A blog about making culture. Since 1999.
notes: Written in 2022, Anil declares the internet is experiencing a new wave of innovation and creativity, similar to the early days of the web. Dash cites the proliferation of web-based apps, the rise of decentralized technologies like blockchain, and the increasing focus on privacy and security as signs of this renaissance. He also emphasizes the importance of building a web that is open and accessible to all rather than controlled by a few tech giants. Dash advocates for a renewed focus on the core values of the web, including decentralization, interoperability, and community-driven innovation.

title: The future of blogging
author: Koos Looijesteijn
description: Good things are coming to the web!
notes: Koos discusses the challenges and opportunities for bloggers in a rapidly evolving online landscape, emphasizing the importance of adapting to changing trends and technologies and creating high-quality content that provides value to readers. He also explores the potential for emerging technologies, such as artificial intelligence and virtual reality, to shape the future of blogging. I can get behind this.

title: No, Blogging Is Not Dying Anytime Soon  - Darius Foroux

description: A well-known author said, “Blogging is dead. People only watch videos.” Sure, visual content is popular. But there are still people who read.
notes: The author argues against video content creators' claim that blogging is dead. Video is not my favourite way to consume information. I still enjoy a well-written article. The key takeaway is to spend your time doing the thing you like.

title: I don't want to log in to your website

notes: This article examines how relying on tech giants for user authentication and advertising has complicated the web. Web developers should prioritise user privacy and find ways to reduce reliance on tech giants. I avoid participating with websites that push "login with x" prompts on me. I shouldn't have to log in to anything to read a simple page of text.

notes: There’s no better time than now to fight for the freedom of the web. While web3 might not be the answer, it has brought the topic of web freedom to the forefront of discussion. Ultimately, the best way to fight for the web is to build. Build and participate in an open and free web!

My experience with interactions with others under pseudonyms has been overwhelmingly positive, as we value our online handles. I love the freedom of expressing myself in my online spaces without being tied to my real life identity.
quote: The ability to remain anonymous when commenting online is a double-edged sword. It is valuable because it enables people to speak without fear of social and legal discrimination. But this is also what makes it dangerous. Someone from a repressive religious community can use anonymity to talk about their sexuality, for example. But someone else can use anonymity to hurl abuse at them with impunity.

title: Why Personal Blogging Still Rules
author: Mike Grindle
notes: This post explores the history of personal blogging, its decline, and eventual revival. Personal blogs and websites used to be a popular means of online expression before social media platforms gained dominance. These websites enabled us to form authentic connections and communities. I've said it before, and I'll repeat it. Let's create more personal websites and blogs to revive the culture of authentic online communities.
quote: Remember when personal blogging was a thing? I don’t mean those things tacked on to business sites or any of that ad-riddled click-bait junk. No, I mean blogs that existed to be, well, blogs. If you are under the age of thirty, you perhaps don’t. But let me tell you, kid - blogs were hella cool. Yet for the longest time, I thought that era was dead and gone. That personal blogs had gone the way of the dodo or the fansite. But I was wrong.

title: You don't need to be an expert to write | James' Coffee Blog
description: Matthias Ott's recent article on writing caught my attention:
notes: If we were all experts our websites would be boring.

title: Blogging Isn't Dead. It Never Died. It's Never Going to Die. Neither Is Personal Blogging - Jeffrey Pillow
description: Remember blogging? That thing a blogger on the Internet declared dead twelve years ago not realizing they were, in fact, blogging at that very moment even
notes: While some have declared blogging dead over the years, Jeffrey reminds us blogging has never really died and remains an essential part of internet culture. Like me, he advocates for a return to more personal, authentic blogging and writing online and owning one's domain rather than relying on platforms.
quote: Blogging isn't dead. Punk rock isn't dead. Zip it.

title: Which self is this?
description: Last month Katherine called out the tension inherent in a “personal” website which is that it is both public and personal, and one’s public (or professional) persona is often different from that of their personal life. Robin Rendle riffed on the concept and said that it’s totally fine for personal websites to be messy or imperfect or weird (i.e., not necessarily how you’d want to present a “professional” front) and declared, in a pretty great and punchy/pithy statement, “You’re a poem and not software”.
notes: Rachel shares her journey about growing up extremely online. She shares how personas change from using aliases to hiding behind the walls of social media to finally being comfortable with letting her personal and professional lives intersect online. It's wild how similar Rachel's journey has been to mine; I love reading about other people's experiences and finding the similarities in our journeys. However, I'm still perfectly happy sitting behind my alias and not matching my personal to professional life. I can't wait to dive in and share my journey.
quote: Like knowing to use an alias to represent my online persona in my first era, I instinctively knew before and during medical school that my online self, who, while earnest and genuine was also a bit messy and still figuring herself out, was not and never could be the self that was expected to show up to see patients.

title: The Teenage Web
notes: Louie recounts their early experiences on the internet in the 2000s. Like many others, he experienced social networks like MySpace and Twitter, which centralised online communities. At the same time, forums and personal websites became less common. While these platforms made it easier to connect with others, Louie laments the commercialisation of the internet through targeted ads and less focus on individual interests and niche communities.
quote: >Welcome to the Corporate Internet. It didn’t used to be like this. The web used to be a collection of independently-operated sites that we all individually controlled. We used to be so punk rock about the web.

title: Why I Blog. You Should Too!
author: Michael Sass
description: Scream into the void...
notes: Mike shares encouragement and tips on why you should blog and how to get going.
quote: You should start a blog. If you disagree, I certainly understand the hesitancy. I was once like you! I’m here to convince you otherwise.

title: Make a Damn Website
notes: This post dives into the importance of autonomy over presenting yourself online. Stop relying on third-party sites spread across the web for your work, profiles or portfolios. Those sites might be convenient, but they do not give you control of yourself and often become problematic. How frustrating is it when a business's details are locked behind the walls of a social media page? Build a damn website, damnit!
quote: I believe it’s everyone’s imperative to genuinely invest in making websites again. For ourselves, for our businesses, for our interests.

title: The Subversive Hyperlink
author: Jim Nielsen
description: Writing about the big beautiful mess that is making things for the world wide web.
notes: Lucky for us, who curate web experiences from the comfort of our homepages, we have no worries sharing any link we find interesting and exciting and want to share.
quote: To some, the hyperlink is dangerous and must be controlled:

title: Give me a web feed or an API for everything • Cory Dransfeldt
description: If I'm using your service, if I'm paying for your service, I really need it to have an API or a web feed.
notes: Too real for me at the moment. Agree wtih Cory as per usual. If I'm using your service, you better be giving me access to my own data!
quote: If I'm using your service, if I'm paying for your service, I really need it to have an API or a web feed.

title: Towards a quieter, friendlier web • Cory Dransfeldt
description: I love the internet, I grew up on it and (probably) spend too much time on it. I found the music I love on it, I've made friends on it, I went to school for business but built a career on the web instead. I often have a hard time reconciling where the web is now with what it was like when I first dove into it.
notes: Great post from Cory. Avoid the noise, avoid the nonsense!
quote: Be kind, be honest and engage on your own terms. Walk away from anything that doesn't serve you and don't be afraid to craft a browsing experience that best suits you. A healthier web is one that's slower, friendly and serves you. Eschew things that make demands of you, insist or impose upon your time and attention.

title: Can We Please Put an End to Overperformed Audiobooks?
description: Britney Spears is perfect and her nasal voice with a Southern accent and just the right touch of vocal fry is perfect. Which is why I was so surprised to hear Michelle Williams, an actress who is a…
notes: As a big audiobook reader/listener, I've noticed this while trying to get lost in a story, even more so after reading this article. When the narrator creates a different voice for each character, it ruins my ability to imagine what they sound like, as I have done for years of reading analogue books. Don't get me started on the accents; they're unnecessary.
quote: Please just read me a story without distraction. I don’t need to hear a variety of voices from a single narrator if a full-cast production is not in the cards.

title: Send links to your friends and make the Web a better place
description: The missing part of web ressurgence
notes: Do you remember when the internet didn't have Google or other algorithms and platforms to push content on us? Back then, we used to share links with our friends over IMs or IRC; we knew them by their screen names. One of my favourite things was to visit Yahoo! and check out the new websites added to my favourite categories. Despite having few tools, we managed to navigate the web just fine. So, don't hesitate to continue sharing links with your friends; they'll appreciate it.
quote: The small web is born from passion, not from chase of profit. Only we can make it flourish like it used to flourish. Simply sending a cool link from time to time to your friends is enough.

title: Read-it-Later vs Hoarding.
description: This morning, 10 minutes ago to be exact, I had the crazy idea of getting a Pinboard account. Why, you may ask? Well, there's this idea out there that you might want to hoard links...
notes: The struggles of read-it-later services. Are you actually going to read that link or just hoard them until the end of the web?
quote: I barely manage my read-it-later bucket, in fact, I don't think I ever look at it, so why hoard links I am never going to look back?

title: The state of the web in 2024
description: The joy of simple HTML-centric web design. Personal websites. The centralized, walled web vs. the decentralized web.
notes: A growing number of people are leaving the walled gardens of the web to find a better experience. Websites don't need to be flashy and overly complicated to be effective; they simply need to deliver information quickly, reliably and without distractions.
quote: Even though a lot of people use large, popular walled web and/or social media services now and still will in the future, there’s a percentage of people who will stop using them. To me, it feels like there’s a clear fracturing happening on the web right now like never before.

title: Apple Annie’s Weblog · Give your blog a name.
author: Anne Sturdivant (@anniegreens)
description: With the initial Blogroll + two spins under my belt, I see some trends and I'm missing some names!
notes: Apple Annie wants you to name your blog. While you're at it, stop using your face as your open-graph image too :P
quote: Your blog's name is more than you! Your blog is an extension of you and takes on a form itself. Your blog is the best parts of you because you are putting things on your blog that you probably don't put out anywhere else in this world. That's pretty special and your blog deserves a name.

title: Using the iPad as an iPad
description: Using my iPad as just an iPad has helped me reset my thinking on wants vs. needs when it comes to specs and accessories as well as to rediscover the joys and simplicity of the platform again.
notes: This post discusses rediscovering the joy of using an iPad, as an iPad. I'm experiencing a similar discovery after a couple of years of trying to use my iPad as a laptop replacement. It can get you some of the way there, but not the whole way. Some of the workarounds are wild and take away the experience of using the device as it should be.
quote: Using my iPad as just an iPad has helped me reset my thinking on wants vs. needs when it comes to specs and accessories as well as to rediscover the joys and simplicity of the platform again.

title: Sharing links via RSS, sharing links via APIs • Cory Dransfeldt
description: I follow and subscribe to a whole bunch of blogs and less and less high-volume news via RSS. It's one of my absolute favorite mediums for keeping up with and reading content on the web.
notes: Cory explains his process of subscribing to RSS feeds and utilising APIs to automate the sharing of links through his website and Mastodon. This practice facilitates the discovery and distribution of links that platforms cannot control. The beauty of the web lies in our ability to share links freely across our websites, allowing for an independent, distributed, and enjoyable experience.
quote: It's encouraging to see more and more folks sharing links, boosting them and blogging them. It makes discovery easier when it's done cooperatively.

title: The Easiest Way to Start Blogging
description:
So, you’re interesting in blogging but don’t know where to start?
I’ve put together this list of blogging platforms that do not require any knowledge of codi...

site: Juha-Matti Santala - Community Builder. Dreamer. Adventurer.

quote: Having a personal website that is not controlled by commercial platforms that is accessible via your own domain is such a powerful position to be in.

title: Not a Product
description:
This website is not a product. (And neither are you) To put it nicely, I am not a fan of the Internet as it exists today.
In my life, I have greatly benefitted from the transformative power of the Internet. A lot of my closest friends and oldest friends are online friends - from Poland to the United Kingdom, I have found kinship with people from vastly different walks of life because I was able to talk to them, ignoring country borders and distance barriers that would have been prohibitive in most other times in history.
notes: Personal websites are not products, and neither are you.
quote: To put it nicely, I am not a fan of the Internet as it exists today.

title: Apple Is Not the Reason I’m Buying Apple Products - These People Are
description:
Lenke til norsk versjon
In the court cases against Epic, this round of regulatory scrutiny from the EU, and other more, Apple has made their sense of entitlement abundantly clear. Every piece of business that happens on their platforms, is to their credit. And developers are lucky to be able to pay them almost a third of their revenue for the privilege of being on their platforms. If Apple understands that their relationship with developers is reciprocal, they’re hiding it well.
I like all my Apple hardware. Heck, I even love some of it! I also like the operating systems, the general focus on privacy, and the way the different parts of the ecosystem work together. But I think I could enjoy a Framework laptop, Asus phone and some Sony earbuds as well! The things Apple makes and does isn’t the main reason I keep buying Apple products. It’s all the fantastic third-party developers, mostly indie, who make great software for the Apple platforms.
notes: A fantastic list of (mostly) indie apps

description: You want to order from a local restaurant, but you need to download a third-party delivery app, even though you plan to pick it up yourself. The prices and menu on the app are different to what you saw in the window. When you download a second app the prices are different again. You ring

author: Jay Hoffmann

title: We can have a different web

Better, yet: we can restore the things we loved about the old web while incorporating the wonderful things that have emerged since and developing even better things as we go forward.

title: If HTML and CSS are so simple, why haven't static sites reigned supreme?
description:
Personal websites are not just about words. The presentation of information about ourselves is just as important as anything we write on our blogs or webpages. Our personal sites are fashion statements. They are a critical part of how we want to present in the world and represent a strong signifier of how we see ourselves and want to be seen.
The reason more developer-minded folks gravitate towards static site generators is obvious– their technical simplicity makes it easy for us to make our websites our own.
notes: Why haven’t static site generators reigned supreme? It's not that HTML and CSS aren’t simple, they both be simple and difficult at the same time. It’s that static site generators are still slightly out of touch with the non developer. Just take a look at what’s getting built across places like Neocities or Nekoweb to get a glance on what non developers are able to do with HTML and CSS and no SSG…

title: House of Nettles • A Sociable Web
description:
The process of building out this site has inevitably involved design choices about how to engage with various technologies and other people's web presences. It's a truism that you can't solve social problems with technology, but social media has made it just as clear that technology does shape the social dynamics that emerge in the spaces it mediates. This drives me to wonder: as more of my friends and friends-of-friends move to individual websites and blogs, what social dynamics does this give rise to? And what different technical designs could improve those dynamics?

I think it's most interesting to approach this question from the social direction rather than the technological. Our first priority should be a set of social goals for interacting on the internet, and only with that understanding firmly in hand can we start usefully interrogating the way technology gives rise to or fights against the sort of…

As some of the work planned for Marginalia Search this year has been progressing a bit faster than anticipated, there was time to implement an unplanned change.
This post details the implementation of a system for detecting when servers are online, to avoid serving dead links and improve data quality, and for detecting when websites have significant changes including ownership transfers and parking.
Table Of Contents Feature Rationale Data Representation Live Data Event Data Change Detection Details Availability Detection Ownership Changes DNS Implementation Hurdles Scheduling Certificate Validation Conclusions Feature Rationale Availability detection is useful not just for filtering out dead links in the search results, but for informing the crawler that it should stop trying to reach a dead domain, as well as a host of other things.
notes: An interesting look at how marginalia detects dead websites to avoid serving dead links

It wasn’t until 2001 or 2002 that I finally got dial up at my house. And I know that my experiences there aren’t all that unusual. You can look up the stats if you want, but the saturation of Internet in private households didn’t take off until the mid-00s.

title: In Praise of RSS and Controlled Feeds of Information
author: Tom Burkert
description:
The way we consume content on the internet is increasingly driven by walled-garden platforms and black-box feed algorithms. This shift is making our media diets miserable. Ironically, a solution to the problem predates algorithmic feeds, social media and other forms of informational junk food. It is called RSS (Really Simple Syndication) and it is beautiful.
What the hell is RSS? RSS is just a format that defines how websites can publish updates (articles, posts, episodes, and so on) in a standard feed that you can subscribe to using an RSS reader (or aggregator). Don’t worry if this sounds extremely uninteresting to you; there aren’t many people that get excited about format specifications; the beauty of RSS is in its simplicity. Any content management system or blog platform supports RSS out of the box, and often enables it by default. As a result, a large portion of the content on the internet is available to you in feeds that you can tap into. But this time, you’re in full control of what you’re receiving, and the feeds are purely reverse chronological bliss. Coincidentally, you might already be using RSS without even knowing, because the whole podcasting world runs on RSS.
notes: rkert writes about why syndication still matters and how sharing content across the open web helps sites stay connected.
